questions.question: A 1-year-old boy, previously healthy until five months ago, presents with a three-hour history of severe swelling and tenderness of hands and feet. The family history is significant for an older brother who had transfusion-dependent anaemia and died of pneumococcal sepsis at the age of 6. Which haemoglobin molecule composition protected him from developing symptoms until recently? A. α 2 γ 2 B. α 2 β 2 C. α 2 δ 2 D. α 2 ε 2
questions.explanation: α 2 γ 2 Correct Answer: A) α 2 γ 2 Explanation: The given scenario is most likely suggestive of sickle cell anaemia. This child did not present with the disease earlier because of the presence of fetal haemoglobin (HbF) containing α 2 γ 2 HbF inhibits the polymerisation of HbS more effectively than HbA , so infants with sickle cell disease typically remain asymptomatic until 5 or 6 months of age when HbF levels naturally decline. In some individuals, higher levels of HbF persist, a condition known as hereditary persistence of fetal haemoglobin , which makes sickle cell disease less severe. α 2 β 2 & α 2 δ 2 are variants of normal adult haemoglobin present in the circulation ( Options B &C) Normal adult red cells contain HbA/Adult Hemoglobin A - α 2 β 2 [constitute 95% and above of all Hb] HbA2/Hemoglobin A2 - α 2 δ 2 [constitutes <3%] HbF/Fetal hemoglobin- α 2 γ 2. Fetal hemoglobin is the major hemoglobin in fetal RBCs during gestation and constitutes 60 to 80 percent of total hemoglobin in the full-term newborn. By approximately 6 to 12 months of age, Hb F is almost completely replaced by adult hemoglobin. ζ 2 ε 2 (Hb Gower-1) and α 2 ε 2 (Hb Gower-2) are hemoglobin chins seen in the embryonal period (Option D). Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 645 https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/neuroscience/hemoglobin-chain

questions.question: Which of the following points best describes the pathogenesis of sickle cell disease (SCD)? Select all that apply. Nonsense point mutation in 6th position of β -globin chain Mutation promotes the polymerization of oxygenated hemoglobin Glutamic acid is changed to valine at the 6th position of β -globin chain Presence of HbF and HbS is protective against SCD. Patients heterozygous for HbS have more severe diseases than homozygous HbS. Individuals with coexistent α -thalassemia have less severe disease.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) C, D, and F Explanation: Sickle cell disease is a hemoglobinopathy caused by a missense point mutation in the 6th position of the β -globin chain This replaces the amino acid glutamine with valine which promotes the polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin . Heterozygous patients (HbAS) are said to have sickle cell trait where about 40% of the hemoglobin is HbS and the rest is HbA , which interferes with HbS polymerization. Therefore they have less severe disease than their homozygous counterparts who have more HbS. HbF inhibits HbS polymerization more effectively than HbA, keeping infants with sickle cell disease asymptomatic until 5-6 months when HbF levels decline. Metabolically active intracellular parasites consume oxygen and decrease intracellular pH, promoting sickling of HbAS red cells, which are then rapidly cleared by splenic and hepatic phagocytes, reducing parasite loads. In individuals with coexistent α -thalassemia, reduced Hb synthesis results in milder disease. Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 641- 642

questions.question: Which of the following conditions does not lead to sickling of RBCs in patients with sickle cell disease?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Increased pH Explanation: Among the given options, increased pH/alkalosis does not lead to sickling, but rather decreased pH or acidosis. Factors affecting sickling: Dehydration - Higher HbS concentrations and increased MCHC due to intracellular dehydration enhance the likelihood of HbS aggregation and polymerization during deoxygenation, facilitating sickling. Hypoxia - Hypoxia induces sickling of cells Less pH (acidic environment): A decrease in pH reduces hemoglobin's oxygen affinity, increasing deoxygenated HbS and enhancing the tendency for sickling. Amount of HbS: Homozygous>heterozygous Interaction of HbS with the other types of hemoglobin: HbSC> HbSA/HbSA2 > HbSF (Fetal hemoglobin has more affinity towards oxygen, thus reducing sickling) Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 641 - 642

questions.question: A 28-year-old man who has received blood transfusions on some occasions and has experienced severe pain in his hands and legs came to follow up. He is currently fine with no complaints and has been receiving treatment that has increased his HbF levels for the past 5 years. Which of the following would be seen in the peripheral smear of this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Howell Jolly bodies Explanation: The peripheral smear of this patient would show Howell-Jolly bodies.They are basophilic nuclear remnants present in the RBC seen in conditions causing asplenia. Given the patient's age and history of blood transfusions, severe pain episodes in his hands and legs, and treatment aimed at increasing HbF (fetal hemoglobin) levels, it is likely that he has sickle cell disease along with asplenia due to recurrent vaso-occlusive crises. There is massive splenomegaly in early childhood due to sequestration. Repeated microvascular infarcts due to chronic erythrostasis and fibrosis causes it to atrophy and shrink over the years resulting in asplenia. This process is called autosplenectomy . Complications of asplenia: Susceptible to severe infections and sepsis by organisms: Encapsulated bacteria Pneumococcus Haemophilus influenzae type b Neisseria meningitidis Bordetella holmesii Bloodborne parasites Babesia spp Plasmodium spp Preventive measures include vaccination against S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae type b, N. meningitidis, influenza, and SARS-CoV-2; and prophylactic antibiotics. Heinz bodies are denatured and precipitated hemoglobin found inside RBCs seen in G6PD deficiency. Bite cells are formed due to removal of Heinz bodies by splenic macrophages (Options A and B) . Spherocytes are small, spherical RBCs without central pallor seen mainly in AIHA and hereditary spherocytosis (Option D) .

questions.question: Match the complications of sickle cell disease (SCD) with their corresponding crises: Complications Crises 1. Acute chest syndrome A. Vaso-occlusive crises 2. Parvovirus B19 infection B. Aplastic crises 3. Splenic enlargement C. Sequestration crisis 4. Splenic fibrosis
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 1-A, 2-B, 3-C, 4-A Explanation: Vaso-occlusive crises include: 1. Bone crises: Common in children, presenting as hand-foot syndrome or dactylitis. 2. Acute chest syndrome: Affecting the lungs, it presents with fever, cough, chest pain, and pulmonary infiltrates, potentially leading to life-threatening hypoxemia. 3. Renal papillary necrosis: Causes abrupt onset gross hematuria due to microvascular occlusion in the kidney. 4. Cerebrovascular accidents: Occlusions in the brain result in stroke. 5. Priapism: Painful, prolonged erection due to blood vessel occlusion in the penis. 6. Autosplenectomy - Repeated infarctions cause atrophy of the spleen. Aplastic crisis in SCD - Aplastic crises occur when red cell progenitors are infected by parvovirus B19, leading to a temporary halt in erythropoiesis and a sudden exacerbation of anemia. Sequestration crisis in SCD - Sequestration crisis affect children with intact spleens, characterized by significant trapping of sickled red cells, resulting in swift splenic enlargement, hypovolemia, and occasionally shock. Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 641- 642 https://www.uptodate.com/c ontents/overview-of-the-clinical-manifestations-of-sickle-cell-disease?search=sickle%20cell%20anemia&source=s earch_result&selectedTitle=1%7E150&usage_type=default&display_rank=1

questions.question: A 12-year-old girl presents to her primary care physician with complaints of fatigue, pallor, and jaundice. Peripheral smear showed sickling of RBCs. What is the most likely electrophoretic pattern seen in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) B Explanation: The patient's clinical presentation with fatigue, pallor, jaundice, and the presence of sickle cells on peripheral blood smear are consistent with sickle cell anemia . The electrophoretic pattern seen in this patient would be B. Electrophoresis is a type of chromatography technique and one of the tests used to detect Hb variants. Principle : Movement of different hemoglobin based on electric charge and solubility in a medium To identify hemoglobin variants, different pH and mediums are used: Cellulose acetate electrophoresis at alkaline pH (8.4) Citrate agar at acidic pH(6.0–6.2) The gold standard for diagnosis of different hemoglobinopathies is HPLC (high-performance liquid chromatography)

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding the different types of thalassemia is correct? Thalassemia major - mutations in both alleles of the HBB gene - impaired production of beta-globin chains. Beta-thalassemia trait - mutations in one allele of the HBB gene - reduced beta-globin chain synthesis. Alpha-thalassemia trait - deletions in one or more alpha-globin genes - decreased production of alpha-globin chains. Thalassemia intermedia - mutations affecting both alpha and beta-globin genes - severe anemia requiring regular blood transfusions
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 1, 2, and 3 Explanation: Statements 1, 2, & 3 are correct. Statement 4 is wrong as thalassemia intermedia does not require regular blood transfusions. A thalassemia is a group of inherited blood disorders characterized by abnormal hemoglobin production, leading to anemia. Genetic defects in thalassemia involve mutations, insertions, or deletions in the genes responsible for producing hemoglobin chains This results in either decreased or absent production of alpha or beta-globin chains. These defects are inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, meaning an individual must inherit mutated alleles from both parents to manifest the disorder. There are two main types: alpha-thalassemia and beta-thalassemia. 1. Alpha-thalassemia: Resulting from deletions or mutations in the alpha-globin genes located on chromosome 16. 2. Beta-thalassemia: Arising from mutations in the beta-globin gene located on chromosome 11. Subtypes include: Beta-thalassemia minor (trait): Reduced beta-globin chain production due to mutations in one allele of the HBB gene. Beta-thalassemia major: Mutations in both alleles of the HBB gene, leading to severe anemia requiring lifelong transfusions and treatment. Thalassemia intermedia: Milder variants and unusual forms of β -thalassemia, also include alpha globin defects in some cases. But the cases does not require regular blood transfusions Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 644-647

questions.question: A 25-year-old male presents with fatigue, jaundice, and splenomegaly. Laboratory investigations reveal microcytic hypochromic anemia with increased levels of serum iron and ferritin. Further genetic analysis reveals a mutation in the HBB gene. Upon histopathological examination of the bone marrow, there is evidence of erythroid hyperplasia with ineffective erythropoiesis. Which mutation in the HBB gene is most likely responsible for the patient's presentation?

options.A: Substitution of cytosine for guanine at position 8 in the promoter region of the HBB gene.
options.B: Substitution of one nucleotide at position +8 in the coding region of the HBB gene.
options.C: Splicing mutation resulting in the removal of intervening sequence-IVS1-5 G-> C in the HBB gene.
options.D: Insertion of a nucleotide at position 54 in the coding region of the HBB gene

questions.explanation: C in the HBB gene. Correct Answer: C) Splicing mutation resulting in the removal of intervening sequence-IVS1-5 G-> C in the HBB gene. Explanation: Among the given options, Splicing mutation resulting in the removal of intervening sequence-IVS1-5 G-> C in the HBB gene leads to β -thalassemia: This mutation affects the splicing process by altering the consensus splice site, leading to aberrant splicing and abnormal mRNA transcripts, contributing to β -thalassemia. Beta-thalassemia mutations are diverse and can occur throughout the HBB gene, which encodes the beta-globin subunit of hemoglobin. These mutations can affect various aspects of beta-globin production, including transcription, splicing, mRNA stability, and translation. Common types of mutations include point mutations, small insertions or deletions, large deletions, and rearrangements within the HBB gene. These mutations disrupt normal hemoglobin synthesis, leading to reduced or absent beta-globin production and the characteristic clinical features of beta-thalassemia. 3-types of beta thalassemia: FEATURE THALASSEMIA MAJOR THALASSEMIA INTERMEDIA THALASSEMIA MINOR Beta chain production No beta chain production. Little chains present. One beta chain is normal. Others are defective. Clinically Pallor Jaundice Splenomegaly Pallor Jaundice Splenomegaly Asymptomatic Hb (gm/dl) 3 to 5 (more severe) 5 to 8 >8 Iron profile Increased Normal Normal Substitution of cytosine for guanine at position 8 in the promoter region of the HBB gene (Option A): Substitution of cytosine for guanine at position -28 in the promoter region of the HBB gene affects the promoter region of the HBB gene, potentially altering the binding of transcription factors and reducing the expression of the β -globin gene, leading to β -thalassemia. Substitution of one nucleotide at position +8 in the coding region of the HBB gene (Option B): Deletion of one nucleotide at position +8 in the coding region of the HBB gene: This frameshift mutation disrupts the reading frame of the β -globin gene. Insertion of a nucleotide at position 54 in the coding region of the HBB gene(Option D): Insertion of a nucleotide at position +41 in the coding region of the HBB gene. Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 646-648 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC10147086/

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman with beta-thalassemia major presents to the cardiology clinic with complaints of increasing shortness of breath on exertion and swelling in her ankles. She has been undergoing regular blood transfusions since childhood. She dies after a few days of hospitalization. What is the most common condition leading to her death?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Heart failure Explanation: The above scenario of heart failure is the most common cause of death in beta-thalassemia major. Cardiac disease resulting from progressive iron overload and secondary hemochromatosis is the most common cause of death in patients with beta-thalassemia major They must be treated with iron chelators to prevent this complication. Other complications include growth retardation, splenomegaly, leg ulcers, hepatic disease, lung disease/pulmonary hypertension, thromboembolism, endocrinopathies, and bone disease. Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is the only therapy offering a cure in these patients. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 763

questions.question: A 25-year-old woman presents to the clinic for routine prenatal care. She has no significant past medical history. Her initial lab work reveals a microcytic, hypochromic anemia. Which of the following statements is most accurate in differentiating between iron deficiency anemia (IDA) and beta-thalassemia minor in this patient?

options.A: RDW is typically elevated in IDA compared to beta-thalassemia minor
options.B: RDW is typically lower in IDA compared to beta-thalassemia minor
options.C: Mentzer index is >13 in beta-thalassemia minor
options.D: RDW is typically normal in both IDA and beta-thalassemia minor

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) RDW is typically elevated in IDA compared to beta-thalassemia minor coexistent IDA and beta-thalassemia traits. This is because in IDA, the erythropoiesis process is disrupted, leading to a more varied size of red blood cells and thus an increased RDW. In contrast, RDW tends to be lower in beta-thalassemia minor as most cells are just microcytic and hypochromic due to uniformly reduced hemoglobin synthesis. The Mentzer index, which is the MCV divided by the RBC count, is more useful in distinguishing between IDA and beta-thalassemia minor, with a lower Mentzer index (<13) indicating beta-thalassemia minor. Therefore, an elevated RDW favors a diagnosis of IDA over beta-thalassemia minor in this patient with microcytic, hypochromic anemia. Confirmatory testing with hemoglobin electrophoresis to detect elevated HbA2 levels (>3.5%) is required to diagnose beta-thalassemia minor. Feature Iron Deficiency Anemia Beta Thalassemia Minor Type Microcytic hypochromic anemia Microcytic hypochromic anemia RBC Less More MCV Normal to low Low RDW(size variance) More Normal Mentzer index: MCV/RBC >13 <13 Reticulocyte count Low Normal to slightly increased HbA2 - confirmatory test <3.5% >3.5% Reference: https://www.uptodate.com/contents/diagnosis-of-thalassemia-adults-and-children?search=beta%20thala ssemia&source=search_result&selectedTitle=1%7E150&usage_type=default&display_rank=1#H1844963031 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6151350/

questions.question: A hematologist is reviewing the peripheral blood smears of three patients diagnosed with different types of thalassemia. Patient A has severe anemia, target cells, and nucleated red blood cells (NRBCs). Patient B has mild anemia with microcytosis and hypochromia but no NRBCs. Patient C has mild anemia with microcytosis and hypochromia but also shows a small number of NRBCs and some hemoglobin H inclusions. Based on the peripheral smear findings, which of the following correctly matches the patients with their thalassemia types?
Which of the following findings is most consistent with β thalassemia major when compared to β thalassemia minor?

options.A: Decrease in HbA, slight increase in HbA2, and normal HbF; HPLC: HbA2: 6%, HbF: 2%
options.B: Decrease in HbA, increase in HbA2, and marked increase in HbF; HPLC: HbA2: 6%, HbF: 90%
options.C: Absent HbA, slight increase in HbA2, and moderate increase in HbF; HPLC: HbA2: 4%, HbF: 20%
options.D: Decrease in HbA, normal HbA2, and normal HbF; HPLC: HbA2: 2%, HbF: 2%

questions.explanation: HbA2: 6%, HbF: 90% Correct Answer: B) Decrease in HbA, increase in HbA2, and marked increase in HbF; HPLC: HbA2: 6%, HbF: 90% Explanation: β thalassemia major is characterised by decrease in HbA, increase in HbA2, and marked increase in HbF; HPLC: HbA2: 6%, HbF: 90% In β thalassemia major, there is a severe decrease in adult hemoglobin (HbA) Leading to a marked decrease in HbA levels Compensatory elevation of HbF, often exceeding 90%. Additionally, HbA2 levels may be normal or slightly elevated. HbA 0-5%, HbA2- 5%, HbF >90% Decrease in HbA, slight increase in HbA2, and normal HbF; HPLC: HbA2: 6%, HbF: 2% (Option A): These findings are more indicative of β thalassemia trait. There is a decrease in the production of adult hemoglobin (HbA),with compensatory elevation of HbA2 and normal HbF levels. Absent HbA, slight increase in HbA2, and moderate increase in HbF; HPLC: HbA2: 4%, HbF: 20% (Option C): This is seen in sickle cell anemia with absent HbA, presence of sickle hemoglobin HbS >75%, HbA2: 4% and HbF: 20% Decrease in HbA, normal HbA2, and normal HbF; HPLC: HbA2: 2%, HbF: 2% (Option D): These findings are more indicative of Sickle cell trait. Here HbA levels are reduced 60-70%, and HbS is present 30%, with normal HbA2 and HbF levels. Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 647 Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page 757, 762 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK545151/

questions.question: A pregnant woman is a silent carrier for α -thalassemia ( α -/ αα ) and is concerned about the risk of her child inheriting α -thalassemia. Her partner has the α -thalassemia trait ( αα /--). What is the probability that their child will have Hemoglobin H (HbH) disease?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 25% Explanation: This couple will have a 25% chance of their child being affected with Hemoglobin H Disease The α -globin gene is located on chromosome 16, and each individual has two copies of this gene on each chromosome, for a total of four α -globin genes ( αα / αα ). Silent Carrier ( α -/ αα ): Has one missing or mutated α -globin gene. α -Thalassemia Trait ( αα /-- or α -/ α -): Has two missing or mutated α -globin genes. HbH Disease ( α -/--): Has three missing or mutated α -globin genes. Hydrops Fetalis ( --/-- ): Has all four α -globin genes missing,incompatible with life. Type of Alpha Thalassemia Affected Alpha Genes Clinical Features Genotype Silent Carrier 1 out of 4 genes Typically asymptomatic, mild microcytosis - α / αα or αα /- α Alpha Thalassemia Trait (Minor) 2 out of 4 genes Mild anemia, microcytosis, hypochromia - α /- α (trans) or --/ αα (cis) Hemoglobin H Disease 3 out of 4 genes Moderate to severe anemia, hemolysis, splenomegaly, bone changes --/- α Hydrops Fetalis (Hb Bart's) 4 out of 4 genes Severe anemia, hydrops fetalis, usually fatal in utero or shortly after birth --/-- Parent Genotypes: Mother (Silent carrier): α -/ αα Father ( α -thalassemia trait): αα /– Punnett Square Analysis: α - (Mother) αα (Mother) αα (Father) α -/ αα αα / αα - - (Father) α -/-- αα /-- Interpretation of Results: α -/ αα (Silent carrier)- 25% αα / αα (Normal)- 25% α -/-- (HbH disease)- 25% αα /-- ( α -thalassemia trait)- 25%

questions.question: The medical team, aware of the prevalence of genetic disorders in the village decides to implement a screening process using NESTROFT for beta thalassemia. They plan to test the result by observing the solution turning clear by checking the visibility of a black line behind the test and control tubes. Which of the following on Nestrof test would be indicative of a positive result?

options.A: Black line visible in both tubes
options.B: Black line visible in only control tubes
options.C: Black line visible in only test tubes
options.D: No black line visible in any of the tubes

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) black line visible only in the test tubes Explanation: A black line visible only in the test tubes containing blood sample mixed with a 0.36 buffered solution is suggestive of a positive Nestrof test. The Nestrof test, also known as the Naked Eye Single Tube Red Cell Osmotic Fragility Test, is a screening test used to identify carriers of beta thalassemia and sickle cell anemia. The test is based on the principle that red blood cells (RBCs) from individuals with beta thalassemia have red blood cells that are more fragile and burst more easily in hypotonic solutions Procedure: Bloood sample is mixed with 0.36% saline solution After incubation, observe the test tube against a black line. Look for the presence or absence of a black line behind the tube. Interpretation: Positive Test: Black line visible in only the test tube A positive NESTROFT indicates that red cells

questions.question: Match the following diseases with their respective antibodies and target antigens on red blood cells (RBCs): 1. Cold Agglutinin Disease 2. Cold Hemolytic Disease Antibody Target Antigen on RBCs A IgM I antigen B IgG P antigen C IgG I antigen D IgM P antigen Select the correct matching pairs:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 1-A, 2-B Explanation: Cold Agglutinin Disease is associated with IgM antibodies against the I antigen on RBCs. Cold Hemolytic Disease involves IgG antibodies against the P antigen on RBCs. Feature Cold Agglutinin Disease (CAD) Cold Hemolytic Disease (CHD) / Paroxysmal Cold Haemoglobinuria(PCH) Antibody Type IgM antibodies against the I antigen on RBCs. IgG antibodies against the P antigen on RBCs. Temperature Sensitivity Bind avidly at low temperatures (0°C to 4°C), but not at 37°C Bind in cool peripheral regions, but complement-mediated lysis occurs at warm core Causes Associated with certain infections (Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Epstein-Barr virus, cytomegalovirus, influenza virus, HIV), B-cell neoplasms, or idiopathic Often seen in children following viral infections Hemolysis Intravascular hemolysis is usually not seen; extravascular hemolysis due to phagocytosis after release of IgM Complement-mediated intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria Clinical Symptoms Pallor, cyanosis, Raynaud phenomenon in cold-exposed body parts Hemoglobinuria, intravascular hemolysis Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 650

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding warm antibody-mediated autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA)?

options.A: It is commonly mediated by IgG antibodies active at 37°C.
options.B: It can be associated with the intake of drugs like alpha-methyldopa and quinine.
options.C: It typically involves the destruction of red blood cells primarily in the liver.
options.D: A positive direct Coombs test is often used to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) It typically involves the destruction of red blood cells primarily in the liver. in the liver, as it is typically seen in the spleen. Warm Antibody-Mediated Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia (AIHA): Feature Description Antibody Type IgG Optimal Temperature for Activity 37°C (body temperature) Common Symptoms Fatigue, pallor, jaundice, shortness of breath, dark urine, splenomegaly Mechanism of Hemolysis IgG antibodies bind to RBCs, leading to phagocytosis primarily in the spleen Diagnosis Positive direct Coombs test (direct antiglobulin test) Hemolysis Location Primarily in the spleen Associated Conditions Autoimmune diseases (e.g., lupus), lymphoproliferative disorders, infections Drug-Induced Causes Alpha-methyldopa, quinine, penicillin, and cephalosporins Laboratory Findings Anemia, elevated reticulocyte count, increased LDH, Decreased haptoglobin, spherocytes on blood smear Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 649
